Failed Food Businesses! Yes, restaurants face the challenge of failing as well, no matter how good the food you’re producing. Did you know that restaurant businesses have the highest rate of failure with 60% restaurants failing within the first year of business and close to 80% failing within 4 years of the establishment? No, we never associate this high a failure rate with restaurants. But this is the grim reality of the restaurant business. Well, it’s no guarantee that if you survived or even thrived for more than 4 years that you will continue to dominate the market. We know that it only takes a few seconds for an empire to fall, you are still running only a restaurant. There are many mistakes restaurant businesses make that can end up hurting and ultimately failing the business. Let’s look at a few of these so you can keep your restaurant up and running for years.
Look at High-Profit Food Business Ideas

INDEX

  1. Licensing and Non-Compliance
  2. Poor Location and Marketing
  3. Financial Mismanegment
  4. Not Adressing Incompetent Employees
  5. Online Reviews and Not listening to Customer Demands
  6. Staffing and Hiring
  7. Quality Management
  8. Responding to changes in Business Environment

1. Licensing and Non-Compliance

In order to even start and run a food business successfully, a restaurant has to be certified by the statutory regulatory of FSSAI (Food Safety and Standards Authority of India). Many times, restaurants either do not register for a FSSAI License or do not comply with the regulations of Food safety set by the authority. Not only does it amount to heavy fines but it ends up hurting the reputation of the restaurant. Frankly, who would keep visiting a restaurant which has been declared not to hold appropriate licenses and has unsafe food practices. I know I for sure won’t!
Check out: How to get FSSAI License Online

Also Read: Documents for Getting FSSAI license

2. Poor Location and Marketing

2.1 Location

Location! yes, it is as important as anything to run a successful restaurant. Location is one of the major factors influencing and shaping the volume of business that a restaurant attracts. You don’t expect just because you have excellent food people will come to your inaccessible restaurant tucked away in a corner of an isolated place of an offbeat path do you? There are plenty of restaurants with as good food as your restaurant’s in densely populated areas where most of the city hustle is going on. People would much rather go to an accessible restaurant than a one where you literally work hard to get to.

Targeting high footfall areas and paths near and about the high footfall areas should be ideal and every restaurant has to identify which high footfall area they should set up shop in according to their target audience. If a restaurant carefully places themselves in areas with high footfall during meals hours, all that is left to do is set up a customer experience and delivering quality on the plate.

2.2 Bad Marketing

if there is one thing that exaggerates a poor location is a bad marketing strategy. Because let’s be honest if your restaurants are marketed and recommended well enough by influential people, location no longer remains an issue because loyal customers always come back and spend time and have food at your restaurant.

So sorry if you do not like marketing, or believe that your “food will speak for itself” but any business has to be well promoted, marketed and recommended to even have a shot at making your name in this highly competitive market.

Here’s a marketing checklist which outlines general items that should be included in the marketing strategy of the restaurant.

  • Accessible and User-Friendly Website.
  • An active Social Media Account across platforms where you post frequently and also interact with customers.
  • Host special events like game night, family night, ever famous Bollywood night, this establishes a culture within the restaurants that generate a loyal following among many consumers.
  • Collect e-mail addresses through the website to offer special discounts
  • Introduce the concept of rewards for your regulars

3. Financial Mismanagement

Did you notice the word business when we say food business? Managing your finances is a big part of managing a restaurant. The food side of the restaurant cannot alone keep the restaurant afloat and neither can marketing strategies save u the important task of managing the finances. This is something restaurants owners have to get organized about with budgets and expenses and ensuring positive cash flows.

Understanding Maintenance, Cost of raw materials and food ingredients, Employee payments and performance, Taxations like GST and GST Returns, Appropriate Menu pricing, Calculating your prime costs all come as part and parcel of ensuring your running restaurants remain a running restaurant. It’s just something you have to do or employ someone to do. This remains one of the major problems restaurants encounter and many great restaurants have fallen prey to poor financial management. Financial Mismanagement is basically one of the most crippling mistakes restaurant businesses make

4. Not addressing Lazy or Incompetent Employees

Restaurants have to get a lot of things right to please customers because let’s face it, good food isn’t scarce anymore. Restaurants have to be run many times like a Fortune 500 company to even register an impact on your customers. So, getting everything done is of critical importance in a food business. In order to accomplish anything, however, everybody in the restaurant from backroom staff, maintenance, chefs, waiters as well as managers have to be working in a coordinated fashion like a well-oiled machine.

Sometimes, however when you can’t figure out your customer retention is low it might be due to a hindrance in one of your processes due to an underperforming employee or management staff.

Here are some signs that indicate that you have a not-so-great management staff.

  • No dedication to continually train and help improve employees.
  • Shift scheduling issues. Always being understaffed or overstaffed
  • Inadequate Communication Skills, Ignorance towards staff interaction, feedback, and involvement.
  • Mishandling the complaints and feedback of customers
  • Showing very little to no initiative to help out or have interest in business side of running the restaurant like accounting, inventory, reporting and other operational tasks.

If any employee like this is still in charge of any operation in your food ‘business’ it’s time to bid them goodbye and bring in something who can steer the ship well out of troubled waters. Keeping on a management employee who has the above-stated characteristics thus, contributes towards mistakes restaurant businesses make.

5. Ignoring Customer Demands, Not caring for Online Reviews

If you’re running a restaurant you’re in the hospitality industry. Hence, one of the deadliest sins would be well, to not be hospitable. A basic understanding of a business will yield the fact that customer demands are at the forefront of driving a commercial property towards success. So listen to your customers give them what they want without overly high expectations, provide real-time value to the consumer if you want to have any chance of being on the radar of people looking for “good” places to eat.

In addition to this, today’s the world of the Internet. Every person in today’s environment will first look at online reviews of a particular place like a restaurant and they would have judged your outlet even before they have ever set foot within your premises.

Not only do good reviews help you, but bad reviews also do too. If a customer has a problem with something they see in your restaurant that is troubling, you can get to know these little nuances and tweak them to better fine-tune the most comfortable dining experience for guests.

Thus, providing real value in accordance with customer needs and demands will only contribute to better reviews and more people searching and willing to pay for valued service your food outlet will provide to them. It is one of the most prevalent mistakes that restaurant businesses make.

6. Making Careless Hires, Not Paying Attention to Staffing

Businesses may require complicated operations and have revenues amounting to a huge load of money, however, all these businesses are run by who? The People. And 1 man is not enough to run a restaurant or any other business for that matter. You need a set of dedicated and focused employees to help portray a friendly, fun yet professional look to your consumers.

It thus becomes an unsaid imperative that only the most skilled and qualified personnel should handle the food and operations at your restaurant. It only takes one clumsy or rude employee to encourage your customers never to return to your food joint.

It’s a general consensus that working in lower levels of restaurant management such as cooking, cleaning or even waiting tables is just a transient job for most of the employees. Thus, it becomes even more critical to hire smartly because if u don’t pay attention you could end up hiring someone who will harm more than help out in the running the business.

7. Compromise in Quality

They say the little things matter the most, I’m not sure how it applies to life, but I am pretty sure that it applies to the restaurant business. Small little details in a restaurant can make a world of difference with paying attention to them bringing you endless praise and ignoring these details landing you up in the ‘worst restaurants’ list, if, there was one.

It’s simple, restaurants delivering consistent quality over time will thrive, those who do not will perish into oblivion.
Without getting too subjective, let’s list down a checklist of things to keep in mind while performing quality assurance checks for the restaurants and the staff.

  • Removing Untidiness, Deploying Cleanliness among staff members
  • Fastening service to ensure customers aren’t enraged by slow service.
  • Delivery times should be as low as possible. Try shortening your radius of food delivery if having problems with delivery times
  • Dishes  very similar in variety, taste, looks tend to disappoint customers
  • A very indifferent guest experience

These little things might not seem like they matter but if these small little things keep piling on to the dining experience of the customer, it could lead to the doors of your restaurant closing down a lot quicker than you imagined. Stay consistent with high quality!

8.  Unresponsiveness to Business Climate Changes

Introduction

It has become compulsory for dhabas, vegetable and fruit sellers, tea stalls, grocery shops, canteens, hotels, caterers, restaurants, and food processors to acquire a food safety license ( FSSAI License ) as per the Food Safety and Standards (Licensing and Registration of Food Businesses) Regulations 2011. This agency comes under the purview of the Government of India, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Moreover, other than these outlets, food safety license is mandatory for the vehicles and transporters involved in such transportation of food to various parts of the country, to acquire this license. The whole purpose of such stringent rules is that the FSSAI is aiming to reduce the problems associated with poor quality food being served to the customers and ensure health and safety.

Types of Registration- Food Safety License

1. Registrations

All persons and petty business operators dealing in food items, with turnover less than 12 lakhs or and quality less than the specified units, shall get registered ( FSSAI License ) under the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006 as prescribed by the Registering Authority, depending upon the product. Form A is to be filed along with fees as prescribed for food safety license.

2. State License

Business Operators like manufacturers, storage, transport, retailers, marketers, distributors, etc with turnover more than 12 Lakh and up to 20 crores or 30 crores in some cases and quantity less than the specified units as prescribed by the Registering Authority, shall apply for License from the State Authority provide they fulfil the eligibility Criteria under State Licensing.

3. Central License

Persons who provide the Food catering services in establishments and units under Central Government Agencies like defense, Airport, Sea Port, Railway etc., with turnover more than 20 crores and quantity more than the specified units as prescribed by the Registering Authority depending upon product are also required to get the Central License.

Documents Required

For the purpose of Registration under the State and Central, the following documents are necessary:

  1. Form A/ Form B, as the case may be, duly filled and signed by Proprietor/ Partner
  2. Pan Card Copy of applicant self-attested. In case of Partnership Firm/ Company, PAN Card of such Firm/ Company is also required.
  3. Address Proof of applicant self-attested. In case of partnership/ company, address proof of such firm/ company along with address proof of authorized representative
  4. 2 Passport size photographs of applicant/ authorized representative
  5. Rent Deed/ Registry Copy of registered office of firm/ company
  6. List of Directors/ Partners/ Members of Society/ Trust on letterhead of particular firm/ company/ trust
  7. List of Equipment/ Machinery installed in the premises.
  8. Partnership deed/ Affidavit of Proprietor/ MOA /AOA
  9. NOC from the manufacturer in case, the applicant is doing the business of relabeller/ Repacker

License/ Registration for FSSAI License can be applied for 1 to 5 years. Means applicant can apply for 1 year or for 2 years or maybe for 5 years. After the expiry of the period for which the applicant had applied for the license/ registration, the applicant needs to apply for the license again as a renewal license/ renewal registration. If the applicant has applied for Registration and his turnover exceeds 12 Lakhs or the production increase more than the UNITS specified for State License, the applicant must proceed for State License.

Introduction

The Government of India established a Regulatory Agency, The Tea Board of India through Section 4 of the Tea Act, 1953 which aims to promote the domestic trade, export, cultivation and processing of tea in India and most importantly providing food license for tea. There are a number of standing committees under Tea Board of India such as the Executive Committee,  the Labour Welfare Committee, the Development Committee, Export Promotion Committee and the Licensing Committee. The Licensing branch of the Tea Board of India is responsible to implement various statutory and regulatory orders issued by the government along with guiding the tea industry with respect to different fiscal policies and legislation and issues several licenses.

Licenses Required

1. Business License

No distributor or exporter can conduct trade in tea without a business food license (food license for tea) granted under the Tea (Distribution and Export) Control Order, 2005.

Application

The exporter or distributor has to apply to the Licensing Authority through Form A.

      • A business license is valid for a period of three years from the date of its issue unless it is canceled or suspended.
      • It may also be renewed for another period of three years.
      • A fee of Rs. 1000 is required to be paid for the issue of a business license.

Permanent License

A licensee wishing to convert their license into a permanent business license has to apply to the Licensing Authority through Form B three months before the expiry of their license.

A business license can be converted into a permanent business license on receipt of the application if-

      • the business licensee is an exporter;
      • such business licensee has not violated any provisions of the Tea Act, 1953 or Tea Rules, 1954 or Tea Board Bye-Laws, 1955 or any Order made under the Act; and
      • the volume of export of tea by the exporter holding the valid business license during the last three years was not less than 1,00,000 kgs annually.

Activities a business license is not required for

A business license is not required for tea exported-

      • By or on behalf of the Central Government or the Tea Board;
      • By means of a postal parcel;
      • As personal effects of passengers;
      • For any non-commercial purposes;
      • As samples of foreign buyers;

2. Exporter’s License

Any person who wishes to trade in tea as an exporter requires an Exporter’s License under the provisions of Tea (Distribution & Export) Control Order, 1957. Under certain amendments made to the Order in 1993, 1995 and subsequently with effect from 2000-

  • An Exporter’s FSSAI Food License (food license for tea), unless suspended or canceled, is valid for 3 years from the date of issue.
  • Every licensee who is an exporter who wishes to convert his license to a Permanent License has to apply to the Licensing Authority through Form CA three months before the expiry of the license.

The License can be converted to a Permanent License if-

  • The licensee is a regular exporter and exports sizeable volume of tea in each year, and
  • Such Licensee has not violated any of the provisions of the Tea Act or Tea Rules, 1954 or any of the Tea (Distribution & Export) Control Order, 1957.

The Permanent License is granted under Form CB with no payment of a license fee.

3. Distribution License

Under the Tea (Distribution & Export) Control Order 2005, no distributor can distribute imported tea except under a valid Distributor’s License(food license for tea).

4. Tea Waste License

  • The granting and renewal of a Tea Waste license(food license for tea) is made under the provisions of the Tea Waste (Control) Order, 1959. No person can purchase, hold, sell or offer for sale any tea waste except in accordance with the terms of the license granted.
  • The License is granted in order to regulate the disposal of tea waste for gainful purposes. It is issued after investigation and scrutiny to bonafide buyers and sellers.
  • It remains valid up to 31st December of the year of issue unless canceled or suspended and can be renewed each year.

5. Tea Warehouse License

The Tea Warehouse License is issued under the Tea Warehouse (Licensing) Order 1989 by the Licensing Branch.

    • An application can be made to the Licensing Authority through Form A.
    • A license issued is valid for a period of three years from the date of issue.

There are certain specifications that the warehouse must conform to for the issue of this license-

    • Shall be fit for tea storage;
    • The walls and the roof may preferably be made of bricks and well plastered, or be made of tins or asbestos, but in any case, the walls and roof must be damp-proof and leak-proof;
    • The floor shall be of pucca construction, properly-cemented and damp-proof ;
    • It shall be properly ventilated, but at the same time protected against pests, rodents, birds, and insects ;
    • There shall be adequate lighting arrangements and electrical fittings should be maintained in good condition ;
    • There shall be an adequate number of gates of appropriate size for easy ingress and egress of tea chests ;
    • The entry/exit gates shall have leak-proof covered sheds to protect against rain damage at the time of loading/unloading of tea chests ;
    • The doors and windows shall be properly secured for the safety of the stored goods ;
    • where the warehouse will store teas other than owned by the licensee, there shall be adequate space for parking/maneuvering of the vehicles carrying teas. The approach road shall be properly maintained and shall have an adequate number of fire-fighting equipment;
    • The warehouse shall store only tea and other materials connected with the storage, blending and packaging of tea. Anything which may adversely affect the quality of tea shall not be kept in the warehouse ;
    • The hygienic condition of the surrounding area adjoining the warehouse shall be properly maintained;
    • No new construction shall be undertaken in an area prone to waterlogging. The existing warehouses shall take proper precaution against the entry of water due to sudden heavy rainfall ;
    • The workers engaged in the manual blending of tea shall wear clean dresses and shall not have any contagious disease.
    • The warehouse must have an adequate number of supervisory, clerical staff and workers depending upon the nature of the business carried out therein and commensurate with the volume of business handled.
    • The Warehouse storing teas not belonging to the licensee shall have the following-
      • Adequate number of watch-and-ward staff ;
      • An adequate number of weighing scales proportionate to the volume of business which the warehouse is capable of handling. Such scales in operation shall be maintained properly to ensure correct reading of weights ;
      • Shall use dumping pads made out of appropriate materials to avoid damage of tea chests while dropping on the floor ;
      • Shall not stock too high which may cause damage to the chests and leave enough space between two rows of stacking for smooth movement of workers and easy identification of chest markings ;
      • There shall be adequate space for office, for receiving, delivery and sorting of teas, for the brokers to draw samples and for blending/packaging of tea, wherever such operations are applicable.

FSSAI Guidelines Regarding Food License for Tea

The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India ( FSSAI License ) has issued exhaustive guidelines(food license for tea) about the sale of flavored and Kangra tea, the labeling for tea products, the composition of tea and the testing and approval of products.

  • The product shall have the characteristic flavor free from any off-odor, mustiness, and taint. It must not include living insects, dead insects, molds, insect fragments and rodent contamination that is visible to the naked eye. The product shall be free from added coloring, harmful substances, and extraneous matter.
  • The tea may contain natural flavors and natural flavoring substances, which are flavor preparations and acceptable for human consumption only if it is obtained by physical processes from the plant origin, either in their natural state or after processing for human consumption in packaged tea only.
  • Tea used in the manufacturing of the flavored tea shall conform to the standards of tea. Also, the tea containing added flavor needs to bear a proper label declaration as provided in the regulation. If the tea manufacturer is providing flavored tea, then they must register with the Tea Board before marketing flavored tea.
  • The tea manufacturers must make sure that the tea is packed and labeled in accordance with FSSAI regulations, whose labeling requirements are extremely stringent. If the requirements are not fulfilled, the manufacturer will be liable for penalties mentioned under the FSS (Packaging and Labelling) regulation, 2011.
  • The label must bear all the relevant and important information before it is ready for sale in the market in a clear, prominent and easily readable format for the consumers. The package must carry a label with the information mentioned below:
    • Common Name of the Product
    • Name and address of the manufacturer
    • Date of manufacturing
    • Expiration Date and Best Before Date
    • Net Weight of the content by volume, weight or count
    • Ingredients details with additives
    • Packaging Codes/ Batch Number
    • Country of origin for imported food

People need to be very cautious when it comes to food consumption. There is no insufficiency of food products in the market and similar is applicable to chocolates. People often get attracted to beautiful and pleasant packing along with the sugariness that the sellers promise. Before buying a chocolate, it is compulsory to check the signs of quality check and its approval on its packaging in order to confirm that the product is suitable to consume. The Government of India has a commissioned agency to ensure the quality of food available to the consumers, known as Food Safety and Standards of India (FSSAI) .  FSSAI, established under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, keeps a check on the quality of food that is being manufactured or sold in the Indian markets by setting up food standards in the country by issuing the FSSAI Food License .

Related: The Benefits of an FSSAI License

On 15 May 2017, FSSAI issued a notification revising the set standards for chocolates. Two new chocolate categories have been included in the New Revised Standards. These amendments and revisions made by FSSAI are referred to as the Food Safety and Standards (Food Products Standard and Food Additives) Fourth Amendment Regulations, 2017. From 1 January 2018, the Food Business Operators are expected to comply with these amendments and regulations.

It is important for the Food Business Operators manufacturing, storing, distributing, importing, and selling chocolates must enlighten themselves with the below-mentioned amendments issues by FSSAI for chocolates and work in compliance with the safety standards set by the association.

Revisions made by FSSAI for Chocolates

FSSAI Revisions

The FSSAI revisions apply to the earlier standards that were set for the use of vegetable fat in chocolates. According to the earlier standards, the use of vegetable fats in the chocolates were prohibited except the use of cocoa butter. In accordance with the revised standards,

The FSSAI revisions pertain to the earlier standards set for the usage of vegetable fat in chocolates. The earlier standards did not allow the use of vegetable fats in chocolates with the only exception of cocoa butter. As per the revised standards, the agency has allowed the use of vegetable fats in chocolates conforming to the CODEX and other international practices. FSSAI has stipulated that the use of vegetable fat in the chocolates must not exceed more than 5 percent of the finished product. While using vegetable fat, the FBO must also adhere to other regulations regarding its source and use in the chocolates.

Labeling of Vegetable Fats

FSSAI license authority has specified the declaration of the labels pasted on the chocolate packaging. The label must mention the quantity of the vegetable fat that is used in the chocolate production. For all the chocolates containing vegetable fats other than cocoa butter then it must have a legal declaration in bold as – ” CONTAINS VEGETABLE FAT IN ADDITiON TO COCOA BUTTER”.

Standards for Vegetable Fats

The vegetable fats can either be used as a single or as multiple ingredients in the process of chocolate manufacturing but they must comply with the following standards:

  • The vegetable fat must be non-lauric, i.e., the fats should be rich in symmetrical monounsaturated triglycerides. They must belong to the following types:
    – POSt (Palmitic Acid -Oleic Acid Stearic Acid)
    – StOSt (Stearic Acid -Oleic Acid- Stearic Acid)
    – POP (Palmitic Acid -Oleic Acid- Palmitic Acid)
  • The vegetable fat should be able to mix with the cocoa powder in any possible proportion and should be compatible with the crystallization temperature, melting rate, melting point, need for tempering phase and other physical properties.
  • The vegetable fat must be acquired by the process of fractionation and/or refining which must exclude triglyceride structure enzymatic modification in conformation with the above-mentioned standards.

List of Permitted Vegetable Fats

Following is the list of the vegetable fats to use in chocolates that have been permitted by FSSAI. These should be obtained from plants as an equivalent of cocoa butter. They are as follows:

  • Sal (Shorea Robusta)
  • Kokum Gurgi (Garcinia Indica)
  • Dhupa Fat (Vateria Indica)
  • Mango Kernel (Mangifera Indica)
  • Palm Oil (Elaeisguineensis or Elaeisolifera)
  • Dharambe Fat (Garcinia Cambogia)
  • Phulwara Fat (Madhucanutyracea)
  • Mahua Oil (Bassialatifolia or B.Longifolia)

Addition of New Standards for Covertures & Praline Chocolate Categories

Coverture

This is a popular variety of high in quality chocolates. These chocolates contain the maximum quantity of cocoa in comparison to rest of the varieties of the chocolate. In accordance with the FSSAI guidelines, the total measurement if cocoa solids or dry matter present on the coverture chocolate must not be less than 35% of the total cocoa solids. Out of these 355, the measurement of cocoa butter must not be less than 31% and that of fat-free cocoa solids shouldn’t be found below 2.5%. FSSAI has also permitted the addition of artificial sweeteners as specified in the regulation’s Appendix A in these chocolates. The labeling declarations must be in compliance with the Food Safety and Standards (Packaging and Labeling ) Regulations, 2011.

Praline

Made in a single mouthful size, praline is a very popular chocolate variety. The chocolate component and its amount shouldn’t be less than 25% of the total product’s weight. Furthermore, a clear notification has been specified in the standards that the chocolate should either contain a single chocolate/filled chocolate/blend of chocolates.

As a result of the addition of new standards for Proline and Coventure Chocolates, FSSAI has now standardized a complete set of 10 variations of chocolates. These are:

  • Milk Chocolates
  • Milk Covering Chocolates
  • Plain Chocolates
  • Plain Covering Chocolates
  • Composite Chocolates
  • White Chocolates
  • Blended Chocolates
  • Coventure Chocolates
  • Praline Chocolates

List of Optional Ingredients Permitted in Chocolates

FSSAI has permitted the below mentioned to be used in chocolates on an optional basis:

  • Edible Salts
  • Minerals and Vitamins
  • Permitted Buffering and Sequestering Agents
  • Permitted Stabilizing and Emulsifying Agents
  • Condiments and Spices along with their extracts

No person shall start or carry on any food business except under a license with exception of a tiny food business operator, but they shall register themselves with food authority. One can register FSSAI in Delhi, Mumbai, Haryana, etc and FSSAI registration for food business has three major categories:

  • State License
  • Registration

FSSAI Registration Central License

Following required to register their business with FSSAI from central government- Export Oriented Units, large manufacturers, importers, food business operators in Central Government Agencies, airport, seaport, etc.

FSSAI Registration State License

Following need to get food license under FSSAI from state government- small to medium-sized manufacturing units, storage, transporters, retailers, marketers, distributors, etc.

FSSAI Registration

Food business operators who are petty food manufacturers can obtain FSSAI registration under this scheme from the state government by submitting minimal documents.

Documents Required for FSSAI Registration

The documents required for FSSAI registration depends on the types of licensing. Following, are some of the common documents required for obtaining FSSAI registration:

  1. Photo Identity of Promoters of the Food Business
  2. Proof of possession of premises (Rental Agreement / Utility Bill)
  3. Partnership Deed / Certificate of Incorporation / Articles of Association / Memorandum of Association
  4. List of food products manufactures or processed or stored
  5. Food safety management system plan
  6. Signed and Completed Form-B

Procedure for getting Food License Online

Food Business Operators can apply for FSSAI online. It is easier and convenient than the offline procedures. This step by step guide will make it easy for you to apply online.

  • First of all go to the official website of government, i.e. the FSSAI site .
  • When the page opens, click on the ‘Sign-up (For Self-Care Portal)’ which is on the right of the screen.
  • A sign-up form will appear. Fill out the necessary details.
  • Remember that the email – ID and mobile number you fill up for a sign –up should be active and valid, which means it must be in use.
  • Make a unique username which is not already registered with the site.
  • After filling up the form click on Register to complete the sign-up process.
  • Once sign-up is successful you will get a message ‘account successfully created.’ You will also get a sign-up success confirmation message on your mobile as an SMS and via e-mail too.
  • You now have an online account with FSSAI
  • This user ID is valid for 30 days so make sure you apply online within 30 days or this user ID will be disabled after 30 days.
  • You have taken the first step to apply for online License/Registration
  • When you are ready to apply for License/ Registration on FSSAI site.
  • Open your page with your username and password
  • Fill the details in the Online Application Form. It will take some time so be prepared to sit at the computer for a while and have necessary documents loaded on your computer system beforehand like filled and signed Form B.

Important Points for FSSAI Online

Once the online form is filled up completely you have to take a printout of the filled out Online Application Form before you click on ‘submit’

  • Once you have the print out then click ‘Submit’ tab
  • Make a note of the reference number that is displayed on the screen once you have submitted the application
  • You need this reference number to track the progress of your application for Registration or Licensing.
  • The web-enabled form is available 24X7  so you can apply any time but keep time available as you must complete the whole application process preferably in one sitting so there are no mistakes and it does not go into Incomplete Application tab.

Introduction

Agriculture and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority Act,1985 constituted an agency of Government of India named as Agriculture and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority (APEDA). Majorly for the development of export of scheduled products by way of providing financial assistance, information, statistics, formulating standards & implementing it leading to the development of scheduled products. Scheduled products are the products specified under the APEDA Act, 1985. The exporters of scheduled product(s) needs to get APEDA registration , and the registration is one time which will be valid and subsisting unless canceled by the Authority. Application of registration is to be made within a month from the date of undertaking such export unless the time limit is extended by the Authority by sufficient cause. The central government is the controlling authority.

Objective

The purpose of APEDA can be explained as follows:

  • Development of industries relating to the scheduled products for export
  • Training in various aspects of the industries connected with the scheduled products.
  • Providing financial assistance
  • Carrying out an inspection of meat and meat products
  • Undertaking surveys and feasibility studies
  • Improve the packaging of the Scheduled products
  • Improve marketing of the Scheduled products outside India

Benefits of Registration

  • It is a one-time registration

Milk Retail (Blue)

Street Food (Purple)

Retail Store (Grey)

Liquor Retail (Brown)

Transport & Distribution (Navy Blue)

The import of all the edible products in India is controlled by the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI). The FSSAI has distributed different controls and warnings, which are to be taken into consideration while bringing in food items. On the off chance that the sustenance items are not according to FSSAI directions, the consignment will be dismissed and won’t be permitted into India. All the entrepreneurs, as well as the businesses that import sustenance items into India, must know about the FSSAI methodology and controls identifying with the import of the food products.

Important Agencies involved in the import of Food Products :

  • Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) , is an independent body established under the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, following the Food Safety and Standards Act 2006. This Act is liable for forming the standards of products and the labeling legislation. It samples and controls each consignment arriving in India. If the food products are not as per FSSAI- regulations, the consignment will be denied and will not be allowed into India. Flemish businesses exporting food products to India must be aware of the FSSAI procedures and regulations relating to food product import.
  • Ministry of Agriculture, Department for Plant Quarantine Organization: this department issues the Plant Quarantine Order. The Department is also liable for the issuance of the import permits.
  • Ministry of Agriculture, Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying & Fisheries department is liable for issuing the requirements for the certificates pre-requisite for import
  • Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution, Department of Consumer Affairs the Department is liable for legal metrology. The Department represents the content of the labeling, but for food and beverages, FSSAI-regulations replace this legislation. The legal metrology is only succeeding FSSAI for MRP (maximum retail price), consumer care articles and net weight.

Licenses & Registration to import Food Products in India

It is important to obtain these licenses or registrations prior to importing any food consignment to India.

The mentioned below licenses and registration are required for importing Food products in India :

  • Private Limited Company or LLP (Optional, however, it is recommended as it improves the transferability of business and limits personal liability).
  • VAT Registration (Required for selling goods or products in India).
  • Importer Exporter Code from DGFT (Required for importing or exporting goods)
  • Product Approval from FSSAI (if the product proposed to be imported is non-standardized therefore, it is not in conformity with the food standards prescribed under the FSS Act and regulations thereunder).

Requirements to be a registered food importer-

  1. The business needs to be registered as a proprietorship, partnership, private limited company or a public limited company.
  2. Value Added Tax Registration with linked authority for domestic sale.
  3. Importer Exporter Code (IE Code) circulated by the Director-General of Foreign Trade.
  4. Product approval if the food product to be imported comes under a non-standardized product category.
  5. FSSAI has an automated Food Imports Clearance System (FICS). An importer may register the required compliances under FICS or for customs clearance on his own or he may hire a Custom Handling Agent (CHA) for the same.

Stages before the import of Food products-

The consignment must pass different stages for clearance and meet the domestic market :

  • Custom Department should clear Application for Custom Clearance.
  • Application of NOC (No Objection Certificate) or Provisional NOC to Food Import clearance system (FICS) of FSSAI.
  • Scrutiny of documents by an Authorised Officer of FSSAI or NOC.
  • Visual inspection of the consignment and sampling thereof by the Authorised Officer of FSSAI.
  • Laboratory analysis of samples collected.
  • Issuance of NOC or Provisional NOC by Food Import clearance system (FICS) of FSSAI.
  • Finally, Custom clearance of the consignment.

Steps to Import Edible Products in India

Related: FSSAI Rules For Food License

Given below are the steps that are to be followed while importing the Food products in India:

Step 1: Custom Clearance

Prior to the arrival of the food consignment through air or seaport in India, the importing food business operator must prepare an Authority Letter in favor of a Customs Handling Agent (CHA), addressing the FSSAI/ Authorised officer. However, while the arrival of consignment, the CHA based on the authorization letter will file an application for clearance of consignment with the Department of Customs established on the Bill of Entry. Post this, a Government Customs Agent will verify the consignment and clear the same after clearance of customs formalities and payment of customs duty.

Step 2: Applying FSSAI Clearance

However, after obtaining the Customs Department clearance, the CHA should file an application in the Food Import Clearance System (FICS) of FSSAI for obtaining the ‘No Objection Certificate’.

The documents required to be uploaded to the FSSAI portal for FSSAI clearance are:

Mandatory Documents:

  1. Importer Exporter Code issued from the DGFT
  2. FSSAI-Food Business License
  3. Bill of Entry
  4. Examination Order generated by the EDI system of Customs, therein requiring NOC from the FSSAI

Optional Documents depending upon the type of Product being Imported:

  1. Import Permit issued by the Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India in case of primary agriculture produce/ horticultural produce;
  2. Sanitary Import Permit issued by the Department of Animal Husbandry, Government of India in case of livestock products;
  3. Registration of import contracts for poppy seeds with Central Bureau of Narcotics, Gwalior;
  4. Certificate of Origin issued by Authorised Person/ Agency at the place of manufacturing/ processing etc. of the food consignment. Certificate of Origin shall contain information on Country of Origin etc. Hence if the consignor is from a different country;
  5. Phyto-Sanitary Certificate issued by the Plant Quarantine Department of Exporting Country in case of primary agriculture/ horticulture produce with fumigation endorsement;
  6. Certificate of Analysis with composition (Ingredients). In the case of Wine & Whiskey – Test Certificate;
  7. End-use declaration – The Food Importer has to clearly declare the end use of the imported food product;
  8. Pumping Guarantee Certificate in case of edible oil imported in bulk;
  9. List of transit country, if the food consignment is trans-shipped through more than one country;
  10. Temperature Chart / Report / Graph, if the food consignment trans-shipped under the Cold Chain Technologies (CCT) from the port of origin to the point of import;
  11. Stuffing list, Packing List;
  12. Commercial invoice as mentioned in the Bill of Entry (BoE);
  13. Bill of Lading as mentioned in the Bill of Entry (BoE) for sea consignment;
  14. Air Way Bill as mentioned in the Bill of Entry (BoE) for air consignment;
  15. In case of an aseptic package, a declaration by an undertaking from the manufacturer that the representative sealed sample is from the same batch of the consignment.

Step 3: Consignment Inspection & Sampling

Once an application is made in the FICS with the required documents, an FSSAI Officer will verify the submitted documents. However, if the application is accepted, the importer will be requested to deposit fees for FSSAI clearance based on the number of samples.

The FSSAI Officer will fix a date and time for a visual inspection of the consignment during which the following parameters will be verified:

  1. The physical condition of the consignment for visible insects and fungal infestation.
  2. The valid remaining shelf life of the product is more than the 60% of its original shelf life at the time of import clearance.
  3. Compliance with the FSS (Packaging & Labelling) Regulations, 2011. The product-specific labeling requirements.
  4. Rectification of labeling deficiencies, namely
  5. Name and address of the importer
  6. FSSAI logo and license number
  7. Veg / Non-Veg Symbol.

Step 4: Food Product approval

If the authorized lab issues an approved conclusion report affirming that the eatables consignment is in agreement with the FSSAI controls. Therefore, No Objection Certificate (NoC)/Non Conformance Certificate (NCC) is issued by the inspector. The food items would then be cleared for import in India and discharged from the Traditional Distribution Center.

Related: Steps to get FSSAI Product Approval

Items without FSSAI Approval to be Imported in India

Mentioned below is a list of food products that can be imported in India without registering for an FSSAI Approval:

  1. Export rejected or re-imported foodstuff implied for re-trade.
  2. Food articles or fixings or added substances which are being transported in Thus, for the assembling of 100% fares items.
  3. Food imported by Diplomatic Missions.
  4. Import of Food for Quality Assurance, Research, and Development. It is transported in sustenance which can’t be discharged into the household to advertise. Also utilized for test showcasing or statistical surveying purposes.
  5. Food imported for the reasons for presentations and tasting, subject to specific conditions.
  6. Food got amid any fiasco/crisis circumstances.
  7. Import of sustenance for sports occasions, subject to specific conditions.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the FSSAI Licence?
FSSAI Licence is given a certificate to all the FBOs that their food products are licensed as good quality of food and hygenic to consume. It’s mandatory to obtain.

What are the consignment clearance stages after the arrival of food products?
?
After the consignment of imported food products transfers India, different consignment clearance stages begin before the product reaches the national market. Here, we bring you details about different stages.
1.Custom Clearance Application requires to be submitted to the Custom Departments
2.NOC (No Objection Certificate) or Provisional NOC Application to be presented to FSSAI’s FICS or Food Import Clearance System.
3.Documents Scrutiny by FSSAI’s Authorized Officer
4.The consignment is visually examined and samples taken by FSSAI Authorized officer.
5.Samples Laboratory Analysed
6.Provisional NOC or No Objection Certificate Issuance by Food Import Clearance System of FSSAI
7.Consignment’s Custom Clearance
Do I require the FSSAI Central License for importing food products in India?
To increase food businesses, several importers are now getting food products from other countries to fulfill the conditions of the Indian consumers. Though this business appears attractive and interesting, various guidelines require to be clearly understood by importers. The very beginning query for them is if the FSSAI License is needed for importers. The government has already complete IE Code issued by DGFT for importing/exporting any products.
How Can I Import Food Products?
To import food products in India, you need to obtain the Import Export Code. The government has set a certain regulation for importing food products from other countries to assess its quality for consumption in an Indian market. After possession of the IE Code and an FSSAI License, a food business operator gets approved to import products. But, the final settlement of the products is given only after getting a clearance certificate (NOC) from FSSAI.
Which are the documents required for FSSAI License for an Importer?
The documents required are :
1.Narcotics Certificate

Which are the additional documents for NOC?
The additional documents for NOC are :

The importer can also apply for temporary product permission if the product’s Harmonized System Code is not in the database. Furthermore, an FSSAI License for the importer has given the system hassle-free to make the process simpler for importers.
What is the validity period of the Import license?
Under Regulation 2.1.7 (1) of FSS (Licensing and Registration of Food Businesses) Regulations 2011, a license given under these Regulations shall be valid for a period of 1 to 5 years as determined by the Food Business Operator, from the date of issue of license subject to payment of fee applicable for the period and compliance with all provisions of license.
In what provisions, FSSAI NOC is exempted for imported food?
In the following conditions, FSSAI NOC is exempted for imported food by submitting an undertaking:

Well, if you are planning to open a cafe, you need to ensure that you comply with all permits and cafe license. There are many kinds of permits and license which are important for your cafe business in Delhi. It is important because you may have to face complications if you have no food license or other necessary documents. The licenses required to open a café in Delhi are:

1. Food and Safety License

It is one of the most important for cafe license. As per the Food Safety and Standards Act 2006, FSSAI License Authority ( Food Safety and Standards Authority Of India) makes it mandatory for all eateries in India to obtain a Food Business Operator (FBO) license. It helps to safeguard public health and ensures the quality of food. You can also file an online application for food and safety license. But, to obtain the food and safety license there are some requirements that need to fulfill. FSSAI issues several requirements which are as follows:

General Requirements-

  1. Display of license/Notices/Certificates etc.
  2. Knowledge of food handling practices.
  3. Regular health status monitoring of food handlers.
  4. Food safety messages depending on the type of food being sold.
  5. Special instructions on the product, if needed.

2. Health/Trade License

Local civil authorities issue the health or trade license. You can obtain it from these authorities in the area where you want to open a café. The FSSAI License will issue to you within 60 days of submitting the application with all the necessary documents.

Documents Required

The following is the list of documents required to get the Health/Trader License for your cafe license:

  • Sanction and Completion which Includes
    • Ownership proof
    • Rent Agreement
    • NOC from landlord
  • 3 copies of the site plan and layout
  • Indemnity bond for Rs.100
  • Structural Stability Certificate signed by Structural Engineer
  • Power and Water paid Bill
  • Sewer Connection Proof
  • Letter from Delhi police is also required for swimming pools, cinema halls and hotels
  • Water Testing Reports
  • Plan of the Premises
  • Medical Certificates of Employees
  • Proof of Property Tax
  • Lal Dora Certificate, if applicable
  • Medical Fitness Certificate of Workers

3. Eating House License

The Licensing Police Commissioner of the respective city provides the eating house license. This authority is an ISO 9001:2008 certified organization. It deals with the licensing of – eating houses, hotels, cinema hall, swimming pools, etc.

Required documents:-

  • Document(s) to prove the legal inhabitance of the Place of Eating House.
  • In case of tenancy, NOC from the landlord in the form of the affidavit on stamp paper of Rs.10/- duly attested.
  • Site design which includes details of the size of the Eating House.
  • Two postcard size photographs of the cafe showing its use as an Eating House.
  • Photocopy of valid NDMC/MCD/DCB/Airport Authority of India trade license and charge receipt
  • Evidence of habitation of the candidate like Election Card, Driving License and Passport
  • An Affidavit on stamp paper of Rs.10/- properly verified
  • Fire NOC, if Seating Capacity of the Eating House is at least 50.
  • Undertaking as to proposed/existing facilities like music and Live performance, dance floor, Bars & disco and so on.
  • Undertaking in regards to the installation of CCTV Cameras with 30 days recording facility.

NOC from Chief Fire Officer

If you are opening a cafe, then you need to consider all the fire safety guidelines. You need to submit the application to the Chief Fire Officer to obtain a NOC. You can also contact the Chief Fire Officer in case

  • Any delay in carrying out the inspection or
  • The issue of fire safety guidelines, or
  • The issue of NOC after the inspection has been carried out etc.

The department does not levy any charges for this job for the certain period of time.

Music license

You need to obtain this license Phonographic Performance Ltd (PPL) for playing music or video in your Cafe. Under the Copyright Act of 1957, the individuals who play pre-recorded music in any non-private, business or non-business foundations must acquire a music permit issued by Phonographic Performance Limited(PPL). If the owner plays the music without the prescribed license, then He/she may face complications o heavy fines later.

Related Topic: FSSAI Rules For Food License

Trademark for Cafe License

It is imperative to enlist your trademark, as it prevents other users from utilizing similar trademarks and to guarantee that you are not encroaching upon another person’s trademark. As a result, you should do your trademark registration .

Certificate of Environmental Clearance (CEC)

This permit is from the EMA for certain types of projects or activities. You can obtain it from the Ministry of Environment and Forests. But you will get it after submitting the questionnaire for environmental appraisal

Shops and Establishment Act

You are required to register your restaurant under the Shops and Establishment Act.

Signage license

You will be required to obtain this license from local civil authorities.

Conclusion

Cafe license is one of the most important parts, if you want to open a cafe in Delhi. It helps the café maintain health standards. Also, it helps to have a separate legal identity. Moreover, licensing add to the goodwill of the café. It is because customers attract more to that place which is safer and holds quality. It will bring customer satisfaction. “eateries operating their business without FBO license will be penalized up to Rs.5 lakhs and jailed up to six months” According to FSSAI officials.

The FSSAI Food License ensures that all the food manufacturers follow the laid rules and [...]

  • 2. Penalty for Sub-Standard Food
  • 3. Penalty for Misbranded Food

  • 6. Penalty for Running the Business without a License

  • 17. Penalty for Contravention of Provisions of FSS Act in case of Import of Food Articles

The Food Safety and Standard Authority of India (FSSAI) is administered under the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare. The authority is accountable to oversee the proper implementation of the FSS Act that has been enforced on various food business endeavors. The FSSAI Food License ensures that all the food manufacturers follow the laid rules and regulations during its operation. A complete guide of procedures has been dictated by FSSAI for all the food operators to be eligible to obtain their licenses. Failing to comply with the guide will lead to punishable offenses under FSSAI Food license .  Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

The entire registration has been categorized on the basis of business category and income:

  1. FSSAI State License – For the business’ with an annual income ranging from Rs. 12 lakh to Rs. 20 Crore.
  2. FSSAI Central License – For business’ whose turnover exceeds Rs. 20 Crore.

The Food Business Operator (FBO) suggests the suitable license type. The FSSAI Act has been entrusted with the responsibility to keep a check on the offenses committed by the food manufacturers operating as Private Limited Company , One Person Company, Limited Company and decides upon their penalties accordingly.

Under the Act, all the individuals engaged in the offense along with the company are pronounced guilty and legal charges are brought against them. In the case of multiple branches of a company, the Head Office will be considered accountable for the misconduct.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

The Director, Manager, Administrator, Secretary or any other in-charge officials of the company, if held responsible, will be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

List of Punishable Offenses under FSSAI Act

1. Penalty for Selling Food, not of the demanded Nature or Substance or Quality

Anyone selling any kind of food to the purchaser’s prejudice which not in compliance with the provisions of this Act or the regulations prescribed by FSSAI, or of nature or substance or quality as demanded by the purchaser will be liable to a penalty not exceeding Rs. 5 lakh. If the person is covered under Sub-Section (2), Section 31 for any non-compliance, will be liable to a penalty, not exceeding Rs. 25,000.

2. Penalty for Sub-Standard Food

Anyone either by themselves or through any other person on their behalf manufactures for sale, store or sells, distributes or imports any article of food for human consumption which is considered to be of sub-standard will be liable to a penalty which may be extended to Rs. 5 lakh.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

3. Penalty for Misbranded Food

  1. Anyone either by themselves or through any other person on their behalf manufactures for sale, store or sells or distributes or imports any food article for human consumption which is misbranded will be liable to a penalty that is extended up to Rs. 3 lakhs.
  2. The Adjudicating Officer is eligible to issue a direction to a person found guilty of an offense under this section, for taking corrective action to rectify the mistakes or such articles of food will be destroyed.

4. Penalty for Misleading Advertisement

Anyone who publishes or is confederate to the publication of an advertisement, which –

  1. deceitfully describes any food
  2. is likely to mislead the consumer as nature/substance/quality of the food gives a false guarantee will be liable to pay a penalty up to Rs. 10 lakh.

In any of the above proceedings, a label or an advertisement relating to any article of food in respect of which the contravention is alleged to have been committed contains an accurate statement of the composition of the food will not help to stop the court from finding that the violation is committed.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

5. Penalty for Food containing Extraneous Matter

Anyone either by themselves or through any other person manufactures for sale, store or sells, distributes, imports any food article for human consumption containing extraneous matter will be liable to pay a penalty up to Rs. 1 lakh.

6. Penalty for Running the Business without a License

Any food business operator (except for the business owners exempted from the licensing scheme under Sub-Section 2, Section 31 of FSS Act) either by himself or through someone on their behalf who is required to acquire the license operates without a valid FSSAI license will be penalized with an imprisonment term up to six months and a fine up to Rs. 5 lakhs.

7. Penalty for Failure to Comply with the Directions by the Food Safety Officer

If a food business operator or importer fails to comply with the requirements of the FSS Act or the rules and regulations directed by the Food Safety Officer without any reasonable grounds will be liable to a penalty up to Rs. 2 lakh.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

8. Penalty for Processing/Manufacturing of food under an Unhygienic/Unsanitary condition

Anyone either by themselves or through any other person manufactures/processes any food article for human consumption under unhygienic or unsanitary conditions will be liable to pay a penalty of up to Rs. 1 lakh.

9. Penalty for Possessing Adulterant

Anyone either by themselves or through any other person on their behalf manufactures or imports for sale, stores, selling or distribution is into adulteration will be liable –

  1. to pay a penalty up to Rs. 2 lakh in case such adulterant is not injurious to health
  2. to pay a penalty up to Rs. 10 lakh in case such adulterant is injurious to health.

10. Penalty for Contraventions

Anyone who breaches any provision of the FSS Act or the Rules and Regulations made by it will be liable to pay a penalty up to Rs. 2 lakh but for this officially there is no prescribed penalty in the Act.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

11. Penalty for Unsafe Food

Anyone either by themselves or through any other person on their behalf manufactures or imports for sale, stores, selling or distribution of any food article unsafe for human consumption will be punishable where the contravention –

  1. does not lead to injury – an imprisonment term up to six months and fine up to Rs. 1 Lakh.
  2. results in non-grievous injury – an imprisonment term up to one year and fine up to Rs. 3 Lakh.
  3. results in grievous injury – an imprisonment term up to six years and fine up to Rs. 5 Lakh.
  4. results in death – an imprisonment not less than seven years which could be extended up to life imprisonment and a fine not less than Rs. 10 Lakh.

12. Penalty for False Information

Anyone who is in conjunction with the direction or requirement under the FSS Act provides any information or produces any false or misleading documents will be punished with an imprisonment term up to three months along with a fine up to Rs. 2 lakhs.

13. Penalty for Interfering with Seized Items

Anyone without the permission of a Food Satefy Officers either retains, removes or tampers with any food, equipment, packaging, labeling, vehicle, advertising or any other additional material that has been seized under this Act will be punishable with imprisonment for a term which might extend to six months along with a fine up to Rs. 2 lakh.

14. Penalty for Obstructing or Impersonating Food Safety Officer

Anyone without any justifiable excuse, indulges in resisting, obstructing, threatening, intimidating, or assaulting the Food Safety Officer while he his exercising his duties and functions under the act will be penalized with an imprisonment term up to three months and a fine up to Rs 1 lakh.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

15. Penalties for Subsequent Offenses

Anyone after being convicted once of an offense that is punishable under the act and again gets convicted for the same crime then:

  1. the person is liable for twice the punishment which was imposed on the first conviction.
  2. the person will be liable to pay a fine on the daily basis where the offense is a continuing one and the fine may be extended up to Rs. 1 lakh.
  3. there is a huge possibility of the license being canceled.

There are chances that the Court may cause the perpetrator’s name, place of residence, the details of the offense and the penalty imposed publishes in the newspaper on the expenses of the perpetrator.

16. Compensation for the occurrence of Injury or Death to the Consumer

A. Anyone either by themselves or through any other person on their behalf manufactures, distributes, imports or sells any food article that causes injury or death of the consumer then he shall be lawful for the Adjudicating Officer. The Court is eligible to direct the guilty to pay a compensation to the victim a sum of –

  1. not exceeding Rs. 1 lakh in case of injuries.
  2. not exceeding Rs. 3 lakh in case of grievous injury.
  3. not less than Rs. 5 lakh in case of death.

It is mandatory that the compensation should be paid as earliest as possible and should not exceed six months from the date of occurrence of the incident. And in the case of death, the provisional remedial fund d=jmust be paid to the next of the kin within the 30 days of the incident.Offenses under fssai act are mandatory for all to follow.

B. In case of grievous injury or death, an Adjudicating Officer or the Court may –

  1. Order the cancellation of the FSSAI – Food License.
  2. Recall of food from the market.
  3. Forfeiture of establishment and property
  4. Issue prohibition orders (in case of other injuries)

17. Penalty for Contravention of Provisions of FSS Act in case of Import of Food Articles

Anyone importing any sort of food article which breaches the provisions of the Act or its rules and regulations will be liable under  Foreign Trade (Development and Regulation) Act, 1992 (22 of 1992) and the Customs Act, 1962 (52 of 1962) be also liable under this Act and shall be proceeded against accordingly.

Also, any such article will be returned to the owner if it is permitted by the competent authority under Foreign Trade (Development and Regulation) Act, 1992 (22 of 1992) or the Customs Act, 1962 (52 of 1962).

The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) is set up under the Food and Safety Standards, 2006. FSSAI is administered by different services and division to deal with food-related issues. However, each subsistence of the business requires a permit from the expert to direct the business operations. It is obligatory for all assembling units, dissemination unit and furthermore for eateries, road nourishment merchants and tiffin services. It is an independent material of the turnover of the business. Therefore, each little, medium and substantial scale food-related business operator needs to mandatorily apply for the permit. The subsistence administrators take part in the business will be issued a 14-digit enlistment or permit number imprinted on the bundle of the item. Given below are the step that must be followed by a food operator to obtain an FSSAI Registration in Bangalore.

Steps for FSSAI Registration In Bangalore

Step 1: Registration

The operator willing to receive an FSSAI certificate in Bangalore has to visit the FSSAI website of the Karnataka Government and create a new login ID in order to proceed further. All the Food Business operators need to provide a unique email address and a mobile number along with a unique username for FSSAI Registration in Bangalore and fill the details to complete the sign-up for the further procedure.

Step 2: Creating Online Account

An account is created once the sign-up process is completed and the user gets a notification via email and SMS. The user ID is valid for 30 days, hence the details need to be filled before it gets closed. After logging into the account, fill all the required details in the online application form and submit it.

Step 3: Obtaining FSSAI License

The application has to be made in Form-B for FSSAI License by the respective user.  The application should be filed with self-declaration, affidavit, and annexure as applicable. On successful filling of details, the system will generate a Unique Reference ID which will be later used to track the application.

Step 4: Submission of Documents

After the procedure is over for obtaining the license, the user has to take print out of the application form along with the acknowledgment and attach the fees demand draft with the supporting documents. The application needs to be submitted with the state authority, at the regional FSSAI office within 15 days from submission of application. The Authority closely examines all the submitted documents and then approves the application.

Related: Punishable Offenses under FSSAI Food License

Step 5: Arrival of License

In the last step of FSSAI Registration in Bangalore, a 14 digit FSSAI Registration number is provided by the Authority which consists of information about the manufacturer and their state. The license is granted for a period of 1 to 5 years which is mentioned at an early stage of application. The license can be renewed after the expiry of its term and the process for renewal should be initiated 30 days prior to the expiry of the FSSAI license.

Registration Amount
FSSAI Registration Rs.100/- Per Year
FSSAI State License Rs.2000-5000/-Per Year
FSSAI Central License Rs.7500/-Per Year

About

When there was a survey conducted about having meals, most of us Indians prefer homemade food. We Indians also travel from one place to another for education and to earn a living. For these busy students and working professionals, there is a feature of tiffin service in India. These people are living away from their families and face a critical problem of daily meals which often leads to severe health ailments. So, tiffin service deals in the catering services of homemade food. It is more user-friendly, provides a huge variety of hygienic and healthy food, everything at an extremely reasonable cost. As a result, the Professional tiffin service industry has gained a hasty momentum in a very short span of time. But, ascertaining license for tiffin service is mandatory. Initially, the entire industry was run by local aunties and was very unorganized and disintegrated without any clear direction. This was primarily because the industry wasn’t taken seriously by the investors and the general public.

However, the shift in mentality has led to the advancement of the industry. Presently, numerous tiffin services are being run by young educated professionals including MBAs and Engineers who detected an enormous gap in this sector. The food home delivery system is a boon in the modern world.

Why do I need a license?

FSSAI License Act (Food Safety and Security Standards Act) states that every Food Business Operator (FBO) working on large scale or small scale needs some licenses. The business could be involved in manufacturing, storage, transportation, catering, sale of food ingredients, retailing, marketing, distribution of food products or any other means, needs to obtain these licenses after registering it under State and Central Food Legislation (defined under the Act).

It is highly recommended that one must take all the possible licenses that might come along the way while operating the business. This is basically, to protect the personal asset of the owner.

It is suggested that the owner must consider creating a business entity such as a Limited Liability Company or a Sole Proprietorship, which can be registered very easily. All you need for company registration are a few documents and the entire process is done online.

It is very important to adhere to the rules and regulations of the Health Department. Before starting with the operation, one must contact the local Health Department to acquire the complete knowledge of specific regulations, certifications, licenses and insurance details. Usually, the Health Department compels an inspection of the area to be used as the kitchen.

Licenses required

An array of licenses/permissions one might need to establish a Tiffin Service of Food in India. These may vary in every Indian State. The following licenses for tiffin service are mandatory:

  1. Shop and Establishment Act License
  2. FSSAI License ( State FSSAI License / Central FSSAI License )
  3. Trade License
  4. Fire Brigade
  5. Police
  6. Society’s NOC

License from Food and Health department- Since the business is that of food, acquiring this license is the essential one. It is advised for the FBO to get contact the local municipality to know more accurately about the state-specific licenses required to establish a tiffin food service in India.

FSSAI rules on tiffin service providers

  • Every small food business operator should register themselves by submitting an application with form A along with the fee prescribed.
  • It is necessary to specify basic hygienic and safety facilities arranged in premises along with self-attested declaration in a prescribed format
  • Registering Authority shall either accept or reject the application giving a recorded reason in writing or notice of inspection.
  • If accepted, the registering authority shall grant the registration certificate to be published/displayed on the work floor anywhere, where actual business is done.
  • The Registering Authority shall take inspection of the working premises at least once a year.

Documents required for food license

  • Form B duly signed and completed along with the blueprint/layout of the food processing/production unit.
  • List of owners/directors with complete address and contact details.
  • Government-issued certificates, certificate of incorporation, detailed list of machinery/equipment used in food production and processing.
  • List of food items prepared a list of surveyors appointed for sample checking, lab report of input material used in products.
  • Proof of place of possession ex- rent agreement, electricity bill & complete information about the food safety management techniques undertaken.
  • NOC from Municipal bodies, other government bodies in case of re-labelers, etc..
  • Other documents as prescribed by the registrar.

Step by step procedure to establish a tiffin service

Select an area of specialty

You can select any area of specialty. Be it birthday parties, graduation parties, company dinners, intimate dinner parties or catering for wedding events. You can operate either in full time or part-time tiffin service business in your locality.

Registering your business

At this step, you need to obtain all the required licenses for the same. The list of these licenses is mentioned above.

Insure your business

It is important to ensure that your business insures your facilities, equipment, and employees against any unanticipated circumstances.

Obtain necessary equipment

  • Tables and Table cloths
  • Kitchen facilities
  • Tiffin boxes
  • Serving equipment
  • Utensils- silverware, glassware, etc.

Come up with a menu

It is advised that you provide a variety of options for your breakfast and lunch for the customers. Make sure you don’t repeat a certain dish for too long as you could lose some customers because of this.

Research the prices

You should know the market prices before setting your prices. In addition to this, take your expenses and your profit margin into account for the same.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is FSSAI?
FSSAI or Food Safety Standards and Authority of India is a regulatory authority that was established under the Food Safety and Standard Act, 2006. The main function is to lay down scientific standards for articles of food and to regulate their manufacture, storage, distribution, sale, and import. This is to ensure the availability of safe and wholesome food for human consumption.
What is the FSSAI license?
FSSAI license is used to grant permission to any food business operator wishing to start any food business in India.
Does one need multiple licenses for multiple food business subsidiaries?
In case each subsidiary is set up in one location/state, then only one license would be enough for it. But, if these subsidiaries are set up in multiple locations/states, then for each subsidiary you need different license.
What if my food business has an annual turnover of Rs.15 lakh. Do I need to obtain the license?
Yes, you need FSSAI state license for such business.
• Turnover of up to 12 lakhs- FSSAI Basic Registration (Form A)
• Turnover of 12 lakh to 20 crore- FSSAI State License (Form B)
• Turnover of more than 20 crore- FSSAI Central License (Form B)
What is the validity period of this license?
The period of validity varies in the case of the FSSAI license. FSSAI can cancel this license any time it deems fit. A business owner is to renew this license before it expires and it can be renewed for a maximum period of 5 years.
In the case of export/import, does one need the FSSAI license?
FSSAI central license is mandatory in the case of export/import.
For what activities, does one need the FSSAI license?
All the activities in the manufacturing, trading, distribution and transportation of food articles need FSSAI license.
When can I apply for the renewal of this license?
30 days before the expiry of licenses, one should apply for the renewal of the same.
What is the punishment for food adulteration?
As per the amendments proposed by the regulator (FSSAI), those who are found adulterating food could face life imprisonment and penalty of up to Rs.10 lakhs.
What are the types of food adulteration?
There are mainly 4 types of food adulteration:
• Milk adulteration: It involves adding water to milk and removing beneficial fats from the milk.
• Adulteration of fats and oils: Usually ghee that we consume is mixed with hydrogenated oils and animal fats. Additive flavors and synthetic color are added to other types of fats to make them look like ghee.
• Food Grain Adulteration: It involves adding crushed stones and mixing sands to increase the weight of the food grains. Water is also sprayed on the grains to increase the weight of the grains.
• Other Adulteration: Used tea leaves are mixed with tea leaves and brick powder is mixed with Chili powder.
What are the different types of contamination?
• Chemical contamination: As the name suggests, it is the case where food has been contaminated by some type of chemical substance.
• Biological contamination: It is the case where the food has been contaminated by living creatures such as humans, rodents, pests or microorganisms.
• Physical contamination: It is the case when the food has been contaminated by a foreign object at some stage of the production process.

Street Food License

If you are into the food business,  it is mandatory for you to get the FSSAI registration to operate in India along with being well aware of the FSSAI/food license display rules. There are three categories of permits that a street food License has to select from:

  • Basic Registration
  • FSSAI State License
  • FSSAI Central License

These are based on the turnover or the nature of the activities that a Street Food License is undertaking. Once the user receives the FSSAI number. The FSSAI number is a 14-digit number issued by FSSAI, displaying certain rules that the user must comply with in terms of advertising the information. Earlier only the 14-digit number was required to be displayed. The FSSAI Registration department in order to strengthen food safety has introduced Food Safety Display Boards (FSDBs) for various food businesses. In addition to the existing mandatory requirement of the FSSAI display, it will also be mandatory for FBOs to display these FSSAI display at food business operator premises.

Rules for Display Boards for Street Food License

Given below are the rules a Street Food License should follow while displaying the respective board:

  1. A sheet of A4 size for FSSAI Registered food business and A3 for FSSAI Licensed Food Business.
  2. Number of FSDs should be displayed: A minimum of one FSDB may be displayed. More than one can be displayed in case the outlet is big in size and FSDB displayed is not visible to all the consumers and food handlers from one specific place.
  3. The material of FSDB: Content of FSDB should not get blurred or damaged over time.
  4. Directions for FBOs: The FBOs may add their FSSAI License Number on the top along with Company Name and Feedback Details on the lower right-hand side for a feedback mechanism.
  5. The Street food display board should be related to the Street food business that a vendor is owning.

Important Elements

Mentioned below are some important instructions that must be followed mandatorily:

  • Display of FSSAI registration /license number of the FBO, which the customer can verify on the FSSAI website.

Contents

  • About
